summary:
They made Daenerys evil in three episodes? It takes no more than three minutes to make Ramsay lovely!
What exactly was the...
body:
They made Daenerys evil in three episodes? It takes no more than three minutes to make Ramsay lovely!

What exactly was the nature of his (not portrayed in camera) mistreatment towards you, Sansa? I say: fake denouncement!

summary: do u know where calling sansa the red wolf came from???
question: do u know where calling sansa the red wolf came from???
answer: From the fandom. Robb was the Young Wolf, Jon was the White Wolf so Sansa was dubbed the Red Wolf. I personally don’t care for it but it’s pretty harmless

reblog.comment: From the fandom. Robb was the Young Wolf, Jon was the White Wolf so Sansa was dubbed the Red Wolf. I personally don’t care for it but it’s pretty harmless

charley. in my 20s. they/them.

stark sisters stan. house stark loyalist.

house stark deserved better than GoT.

weakness: can't like things casually.

most recently was teamhousestark.
on tumblr since '08.

multishipper, but mainly
gendrya, femslash, and slash.

summary: all that you are is all that I'll ever need - everdeenwayland - Game of Thrones (TV) [Archive of Our Own]
title: all that you are is all that I'll ever need - everdeenwayland - Game of Thrones (TV) [Archive of Our Own]
excerpt: An Archive of Our Own, a project of the Organization for Transformative Works
description:
Chapters: ¼

Fandom: asoiaf, game of thrones

Warnings: Creator Chose Not To Use Archive Warnings

Relationships: Theon Greyjoy/Sansa Stark

Characters: Sansa Stark, Theon Greyjoy, Robb Stark, Yara Greyjoy, Alannys Greyjoy.

Additional Tags: Alternate Universe - Modern Setting, Fake/Pretend Relationship, pining, slowburn

Summary:In retrospective, she should have seen this was a bad idea, wait, not exactly a bad idea but the worst idea ever. (The truth is that she kind of knew that, the truth is that she hadn’t care at all when she agreed to it, and, the truth is that she fucking cares now.)

So, that’s the thing, Theon Greyjoy, aka her former teenager crush, wants to fake date her for a day.


Or the fake date au no one asked for.

blog.description: I want very much for you to be happy, Sansa

title: A Wolf in Spring
body:
read it on the AO3 at http://bit.ly/2XbM5td

by Revans_Mask

After enduring countless tragedies, Sansa and Margaery finally found love together and thwarted Littlefinger’s schemes for them, but now winter has come. With Daenerys riding north to Winterfell and the Night King invading, the two women will be tested as never before. The sequel to “A Rose in Winter.”

Words: 2741, Chapters: 1/?, Language: English

Series: Part 2 of The Wolf and the Rose

  • Fandoms: Game of Thrones (TV)
  • Rating: Explicit
  • Warnings: Graphic Depictions Of Violence, Major Character Death
  • Categories: F/F
  • Characters: Sansa Stark, Margaery Tyrell, Arya Stark, Bran Stark, Jon Snow, Theon Greyjoy, Daenerys Targaryen, Brienne of Tarth, Jaime Lannister, Olenna Tyrell
  • Relationships: Sansa Stark/Margaery Tyrell, Jon Snow/Daenerys Targaryen, Arya Stark/Gendry Waters, Jaime Lannister/Brienne of Tarth
  • Additional Tags: And all the rest - Freeform, Alternate Universe - Canon Divergence, Politics, Smut, Emotional Hurt/Comfort, Established Relationship, Period-Typical Homophobia, Season 8


read it on the AO3 at http://bit.ly/2XbM5td

title: A Series Of Lemony Events
body:
Yesterday, I baked a lemon cake. Though time seems to trickle from between my fingertips more surely than flour does, my hands smell of lemon and butter and sometimes I bring them to my face to inhale the brightness. When the sunshine from my hands and day fade, there will be cake, a quivering wobble of gold, as it cools on the rack. Though time does not seem to be on my side, I have promised my family cake for breakfast tomorrow and for now, that seems like enough.

It has been two weeks of summer already. The days slip by fast, falling into each other so surely that I now mark the passing by the differences in bird calls each morning. This morning, the owl sounded hoarse, the tail ends of its coos melting into a whisper. I worry it is contracting a cough from the days of rain lately. Four days ago, it hooted at seven in the morning and I woke the whole house, in a rush of thinking, dreaming that I had overslept, for the sun was out and about, along with a neighbor who had decided that seven in the morning was the right time to mow the lawn.

In Killing Commendatore, the main character finds an owl, whose roost leads him to find a painting that sets off a series of events. Each event is strange, but in the moment, everything seems natural. This I find to be true of my ordinary life, for the events that have led me to this lemon cake have seemed to be normal. However, when examined more closely, they are out of the ordinary, something as extraordinary as hearing the howl of a quiet, unseen bird.

I have wanted to bake this cake for awhile now. In a turn of events, that isolated seem ordinary, but as a whole, strange, I did finally bake this cake. This cake makes me think of Sansa Stark, in many ways. When first mixed, it wobbles, pale and soft with the innocence of butter and milk that have not met fire. Pulled from the oven, I found it to grow to a towering height. It emerged cracked in some places, on the whole, it was golden and statuesque. Though this cake does not bear as much structural integrity as many of its counterparts in the realm of quick breads, it stands its ground quite well, especially when cloaked in a healthy dollop of cream. Its tart, but not enough to make your mouth pucker. Its sweet, but not enough to make your teeth ache. It is enough to make you nod, because though the cake is light, there is something else there, something that deserves another bite.

I hope that your life may unfold in a series of events that lead to this lemon cake. I hope that mine will do so again so, for I have spied three lemons on the counter.

You can find the recipe for this richness here.
body_abstract: Yesterday, I baked a lemon cake. Though time seems to trickle from between my fingertips more surely than flour does, my hands smell of lemon and butter and sometimes I bring them to my face to inhale the brightness. When the sunshine from my hands and day fade, there will be cake, a quivering wobble of gold, as it cools on the rack. Though time does not seem to be on my side, I have promised my family cake for breakfast tomorrow and for now, that seems like enough.

In Killing Commendatore, the main character finds an owl, whose roost leads him to find a painting that sets off a series of events. Each event is strange, but in the moment, everything seems natural. This I find to be true of my ordinary life, for the events that have led me to this lemon cake have seemed to be normal. However, when examined more closely, they are out of the ordinary, something as extraordinary as hearing the howl of a quiet, unseen bird.

I have wanted to bake this cake for awhile now. In a turn of events, that isolated seem ordinary, but as a whole, strange, I did finally bake this cake. This cake makes me think of Sansa Stark, in many ways. When first mixed, it wobbles, pale and soft with the innocence of butter and milk that have not met fire. Pulled from the oven, I found it to grow to a towering height. It emerged cracked in some places, on the whole, it was golden and statuesque. Though this cake does not bear as much structural integrity as many of its counterparts in the realm of quick breads, it stands its ground quite well, especially when cloaked in a healthy dollop of cream. Its tart, but not enough to make your mouth pucker. Its sweet, but not enough to make your teeth ache. It is enough to make you nod, because though the cake is light, there is something else there, something that deserves another bite.

I hope that your life may unfold in a series of events that lead to this lemon cake. I hope that mine will do so again so, for I have spied three lemons on the counter.

You can find the recipe for this richness here.

trail.content_raw:
Yesterday, I baked a lemon cake. Though time seems to trickle from between my fingertips more surely than flour does, my hands smell of lemon and butter and sometimes I bring them to my face to inhale the brightness. When the sunshine from my hands and day fade, there will be cake, a quivering wobble of gold, as it cools on the rack. Though time does not seem to be on my side, I have promised my family cake for breakfast tomorrow and for now, that seems like enough.

[[MORE]]

It has been two weeks of summer already. The days slip by fast, falling into each other so surely that I now mark the passing by the differences in bird calls each morning. This morning, the owl sounded hoarse, the tail ends of its coos melting into a whisper. I worry it is contracting a cough from the days of rain lately. Four days ago, it hooted at seven in the morning and I woke the whole house, in a rush of thinking, dreaming that I had overslept, for the sun was out and about, along with a neighbor who had decided that seven in the morning was the right time to mow the lawn.

In Killing Commendatore, the main character finds an owl, whose roost leads him to find a painting that sets off a series of events. Each event is strange, but in the moment, everything seems natural. This I find to be true of my ordinary life, for the events that have led me to this lemon cake have seemed to be normal. However, when examined more closely, they are out of the ordinary, something as extraordinary as hearing the howl of a quiet, unseen bird.

I have wanted to bake this cake for awhile now. In a turn of events, that isolated seem ordinary, but as a whole, strange, I did finally bake this cake. This cake makes me think of Sansa Stark, in many ways. When first mixed, it wobbles, pale and soft with the innocence of butter and milk that have not met fire. Pulled from the oven, I found it to grow to a towering height. It emerged cracked in some places, on the whole, it was golden and statuesque. Though this cake does not bear as much structural integrity as many of its counterparts in the realm of quick breads, it stands its ground quite well, especially when cloaked in a healthy dollop of cream. Its tart, but not enough to make your mouth pucker. Its sweet, but not enough to make your teeth ache. It is enough to make you nod, because though the cake is light, there is something else there, something that deserves another bite.

I hope that your life may unfold in a series of events that lead to this lemon cake. I hope that mine will do so again so, for I have spied three lemons on the counter.

You can find the recipe for this richness here.

summary: Sansa Stark Appreciation Week 2019 | Day 2 “I will remember, Your Grace,“ said Sansa, though she had always heard that love was...
caption:
Sansa Stark Appreciation Week 2019 | Day 2

“I will remember, Your Grace,“ said Sansa, though she had always heard that love was a surer route to the people’s loyalty than fear. If I am ever a queen, I’ll make them love me. - Sansa Stark, A Clash of Kings.
